holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil proceedings include all affecting civil/private rights not criminal; writ petition concerns civil rights; follows Narayan Row precedent.

holdings.text: Art.133(1) covers any judgment, decree or final order in civil proceedings including those in extraordinary original jurisdiction under Art.226, not limited to appellate or ordinary original jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The first requisite for the application of Art. 133(1) is thus satisfied. The next question is what are the different kinds of decisions from which appeals lie under Art. 133. Mr. Gupta's contention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad textual interpretation of 'any judgment, decree or final order'; discards historical CPC ss.109/110 distinctions; aware of new Art.226 jurisdiction.

holdings.text: An order summarily dismissing a petition under Art.226 is a final order under Art.133 as it terminates the special proceeding and decides the jurisdictional issue.

anchor.surface_text: A decision in the exercise of this jurisdiction, whether interfering with the proceeding impugned or declining to do so, is a final decision in so far as the High Court is concerned because it terminates finally the special proceeding before it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ jurisdiction independent of original controversy; finality in terminating High Court proceeding re jurisdiction, unlike appellate/revisional contexts.

holdings.text: The appellants were entitled to a certificate as of right under Art.133(1)(a) or (b); High Court erred in refusing it.

anchor.surface_text: The order dated February 1, 1965 is set aside and the case will go back to the High Court for disposal according to law. The first respondent shall bear the costs of the appellant.

precedents.cited_proposition: Claims Officer had jurisdiction to pronounce on the character of the debt (overruling Ramkrishna v. Board of Revenue)

precedents.citation: S. A. L. Narayan Row and another, etc. v. Ishwarlal Bhagwandas and another, etc. 1

anchor.surface_text: S. A. L. Narayan Row and another, etc. v. Ishwarlal Bhagwandas and another, etc. 1 . Shah J, speaking for the majority, first summarises all the provisions in the Constitution bearing upon appeals to this Court and after analysis, holds that the words civil proceeding are used in the widest sense, that in contradistinction to criminal proceedings they cover all proceedings which affect directly civil rights. A proceeding under Art. 226 for a writ to bring up a proceeding for consideration must be a civil proceeding, if the original proceeding concerned civil rights.

precedents.case_name: S. A. L. Narayan Row v. Ishwarlal Bhagwandas
precedents.cited_proposition: civil proceeding used in widest sense to cover all proceedings affecting civil rights in contradistinction to criminal proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: the words civil proceeding are used in the widest sense, that in contradistinction to criminal proceedings they cover all proceedings which affect directly civil rights

precedents.citation: Municipal Officer, Aden v. Abdul Karim 1

anchor.surface_text: Municipal Officer, Aden v. Abdul Karim 1  this distinction in fact was made and the provisions of the amended cl.  40  of the Letters Patent of the Bombay High Court were called in aid. Mr. Gupta cannot avail himself of the same argument in view of the use of the words any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court in the opening part of Art. 133 1 . Article 133 not only discards the distinction between appellate and original jurisdictions but deliberately used words which are as wide as language can make them.
